data.title: Clock Angles
data.statement:
Given a time [[T]] (<<12-hour format, HH:MM>>) a number [[H]], and a number [[M]], output the smallest angle between the <<hour hand and minute hand according to [[T]]>>, the <<hour hand according to [[T]] and hour hand according to [[H]]>>, and the <<minute hand according to [[T]] and minute hand according to [[M]]>>.  All angles should be in degrees.

<<NOTE:>> For every minute, the hour hand will also move an equal distance to the next hour value.  For example, given a time [[T]] of 09:15, the angle of the hour hand will NOT be horizontal.  [[H]] and [[M]] are independent, so when calculating the angle between the hour hand according to [[T]] and the hour hand according to [[H]], consider the time to be [[H]] o'clock.
data.constraints:
Reading strings
<<Length of [[T]] is always 5 characters>>
<<Length of [[H]] is either 1 or 2 characters>>
<<Length of [[M]] is always 2 characters>>

Integer Values
<<1<=[[H]]<=12>>
<<0<=[[M]]<=59>>
data.stubGenerator:
read T:string(5)
read H:string(2)
read M:string(2)

write Answer
data.inputDescription:
Three separate lines:
[[T]]: A time, represented in 12-hour format <<HH:MM>> (Single-digit hours are represented with a leading 0, e.g. 09:00 as opposed to 9:00)
[[H]]: A value between 1 and 12 inclusive (No leading 0 for single-digit hours)
[[M]]: A value between 1 and 59 inclusive
data.outputDescription:
Three separate lines:
<<Line 1>>: Smallest angle between the hour hand and the minute hand
<<Line 2>>: Smallest angle between the hour hand and [[H]]
<<Line 3>>: Smallest angle between the minute hand and [[M]]

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Given a time T (12-hour format, HH:MM) a number H, and a number M, output the smallest angle between the hour hand and minute hand according to T, the hour hand according to T and hour hand according to H, and the minute hand according to T and minute hand according to M. All angles should be in degrees.

NOTE: For every minute, the hour hand will also move an equal distance to the next hour value. For example, given a time T of 09:15, the angle of the hour hand will NOT be horizontal. H and M are independent, so when calculating the angle between the hour hand according to T and the hour hand according to H, consider the time to be H o'clock.
Input
Three separate lines:
T: A time, represented in 12-hour format HH:MM (Single-digit hours are represented with a leading 0, e.g. 09:00 as opposed to 9:00)
H: A value between 1 and 12 inclusive (No leading 0 for single-digit hours)
M: A value between 1 and 59 inclusive
Output
Three separate lines:
Line 1: Smallest angle between the hour hand and the minute hand
Line 2: Smallest angle between the hour hand and H
Line 3: Smallest angle between the minute hand and M
Constraints
Reading strings
Length of T is always 5 characters
Length of H is either 1 or 2 characters
Length of M is always 2 characters

Integer Values
1<=H<=12
0<=M<=59
Example
Input
09:00
12
30
Output
90
90
180
